title: Thursday, 3rd May, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE11:02am

Hello! Welcome, hi, good morning, hey.

BE11:02am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's etc etc etc.

Soundbuy Morning
Plato the Cook Good morning
Underminer Good morning
BE11:03am

We've been slack with starting on a picture recently. Let's fix that.

11:03 am
BE11:03am

BintmeisterGeneral Who are these happy chappies

Soundbuy The Secret Seven?
BE11:04am

Those healthy young folks are from Imperial College Business School.

BE11:04am

Masters students launch investment fund at Imperial College Business School

11:04 am
BE11:04am

A team of students from Imperial College Business School have collaborated to create and launch the School’s first student-led investment fund.

The “Imperial College Business School Student Investment Fund” has been established by students from the School’s MSc Investment and Wealth Management, and the MSc Financial Accounting programmes with the core mission of equipping them and their fellow classmates with the necessary practical skills to work in a buy-side role within the financial sector.

By managing £100,000 in assets, courtesy of the College’s endowment, the investment fund will provide students with another method of learning financial skills, in addition to the content of their degree curriculums. By working with external companies, the investment fund will also help to connect ambitious students with potential future employers.

Underminer @plato, usually because they are short.
BE11:05am

More info here: https://www.imperi...t-investment-fund/

pancakes or waffles *shorter
TKZ Good luck with that. Cantab quant fund is struggling.

urgeview Lambs to the slaughter...

11:06 am

TKZ One researcher once constructed a portfolio by blindfolding a monkey and making it throw darts at companies' names appearing on a newspaper. And it performed just as well as any other. WSJ repeated that experiment with its staff writers (of course they are not blind-folded). But the result the same.

And a percentage point cut off full-year guidance, mostly because sales of its Bioactives wound management thing seem to be going south at an alarming rate.

Shinshin @Lemmy, ha yes, plus also practicing those calls "hi, I see you've printed me at 104.8 but I was really rather expecting 106.1 or better. Oh, 106.2 ? That's more in line, thank you"

Here's Goldman.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

1Q18 organic revenue growth of -0.1% was 110bp below GSe.
On a divisional basis, Advanced surgical devices growth was 80bp below GSe, while Advanced wound management was 190bp below. The softness in the quarter was broad-based, with only sports medicine and advanced wound care meeting and/or exceeding our expectations.

VV75 I've seen many fresh faced chaps step onto the trading floor with sure fire theories and heaps of confidence, only to be punished time and again by reality of the erratic market.
tonyb S&N: i was under the feeling that the bad winter would have increased bone fractures, needing the NHS to buy more orthopedic inserts (tibial nails make 80% margin)...
BE11:13am

Lowered FY18 guidance implies 3% downside to consensus: Smith & Nephew now expects 2018 organic revenue growth of 2-3%, down from 3-4% (GSe: 3.1%) and reported revenue growth of 5-6% (GSe: 6.6%; consensus 7.4%). The company expects the trading profit margin to be at or above the 2017 levels of 22.0%; this compares to a 30-70bp improvement previously (GSe and consensus are 22.4%). Net-net, we calculate that the revised guidance implies a 2-4% downside to consensus adjusted profit.

Miss Piggy @Plato, women tend to be shorter hence front row.
BE11:13am

They're neutral.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

We forecast 3.5% average organic revenue growth (2018-21E), which, combined with modest operating leverage, drives an EBIT CAGR of 6.2%, and EPS CAGR of 6.1% (both 2017-2021E). In the context of this outlook, we find the current 18x P/E multiple (2019E; vs. EU Medtech on 22x for 10.8% EPS CAGR) as appropriate, hence our Neutral rating.

BE11:14am

And Jefferies to talk us through what happened divisionally.

BE11:14am

Familiar divisional trends but more negatives than positives; heavily reliant on EMs again. Sports Med continued as the bright spot (+6%), driven by shoulder, and Knees performed well despite lower procedural volumes (+2%), outperforming all others but SYK (see below), driven by Journey II and LEGION (revision knee system). Other Surgical remained strong at +9%. AWD slowed to +2%, partly impacted by a strong comp (+16%). Other numbers were disappointing: Hips declined -2%. AET declined -5%, still impacted by competition despite having launched two new products since last year. AWC remained soft (+0%). Trauma fell -2%. Bioactives fell -12% impacted by sales pattern in SANTYL. Across the group, the geographical trends have continued. US weak (-2%) while Other Established Markets declined -2% and EM drove performance with +9%.

PeterC @pancakes - neither, artisan sourdough made from carefully curated grains of spelt wheat (single origin)
11:14 am
BE11:15am

And Cazenove to say: "they went up a lot."

BE11:15am

The stock has performed strongly over the last 3 months, up 13%, out-performing the FTSE by 15% and the European healthcare sector by 17%, recovering from the lows with decent FY results, the new cost savings programme and most recently the announcement of a new CEO. The shares therefore look vulnerable to a de-rating in the near term. We expect the shares to be off c5%.

BE11:15am

The basic argument here is dead simple.

BE11:20am

Glencore delivered a stable production result with copper and nickel the highlights. Zinc, ferrochrome and oil were all weaker vs Q1 2017 however. Encouragingly, marketing EBIT is now guided to be within the top half of the USD2.2-3.2bn long-term guidance range. Production guidance implies a material improvement off 2017’s relatively weak base, as GLEN releases latent capacity but as stated by management, this is set to be weighted towards the second half of the year.

urgeview Desire ?
TKZ In early 2016 when commodities were seriously battered. Some of the energy bonds were trading at 10c to a dollar (Whiting, Ultra Petroleum, CRC, Chesapeake, you name it). Now most of them were back in 80c level. And the amount of interest you earned over the two years. That was the serious money.
BE11:41am

We’ve spent the day parsing what drove the $80 million EBITDA shortfall vs. our numbers and we think it’s important to note that it was not in any way explained by the $50 million tax provision lap in Europe, as that was firmly built into our estimates and in our view wasn’t relevant to the discussion. With that as context, we’re admittedly a bit frustrated by the lack of communication about what differed versus the company plan. Ultimately, the issue seems to be as simple as organic sales being much worse than expected (-4.5%, or -4% below our estimate) given weakness across the board and in the critical U.S. market in particular (shipment volume -6.7%, STRs -3.8%). To be sure, there were several one-off items that impacted 1Q, including poor weather in key markets and supply chain disruption in the U.S. At the same time, we think the revenue miss coupled with a dramatic EBITDA shortfall highlighted the market’s greatest fears for TAP, namely that industry volume softness might ultimately prove too much for it to offset via cost savings. We’d call the concerns around accelerating industry change (e.g. premiumization, category shifts across alcohol) and the rise of legal cannabis the “elephant in the room” for TAP holders attracted by valuation & cash flow dynamics.

BE11:41am

For now, we’re assuming that this quarter’s dramatic miss stemmed more from a confluence of one-time events (e.g. weather, order system issues) than a step-change in the trajectory of TAP’s business. With FY expectations now tempered and TAP trading at an ~11.5% FCF yield, with ample FCF to de-lever and accelerate shareholder returns next year (~$1.5bn), we think shares will re-gain ground from here. That said, this remains a “show me” story and we’re ever cognizant of the many structural issues facing the business and the inherent risks they carry. PT to $74 from $94.

Ted Baker has a number of concessions, probably skewed towards larger stores, but Superdry is down to two. HOF has been in decline for a while and morale must, unfortunately, be low. Its travails may represent a bit of help for other department stores, but again, the scale of HOF’s discomfort betrays its overly indebted structure rather than unbearable conditions on the High Street. Should outlets close, a number will comply with Sports Direct’s requirements for “elevated stores”, but we do not expect an unseemly clamour for the space.

Quite interesting note from Barclays about fibre.

BornCynic BE - I thought we were investing ?
BE11:59am

Until recently it was almost unthinkable that any company would consider creating a third expensive parallel Telecom infrastructure, competing with EU incumbents and cable, given the high barrier to entry/cost of rollout, relatively stable competition plus mature nature of the industry. However, we are now seeing strategic moves across a number of European markets, with Open Fiber in Italy the highest profile case study, and others following. In this detailed report we analyse Open Fiber’s prospects, its key success factors, and identify risks to other EU markets. We conclude that Italy is in many ways a “perfect storm”, creating a fertile investment opportunity for alternative infrastructure. Only Germany and the UK are likely to see wholesale only on a similar scale, given low incumbent FTTH builds and high service provider interest. Today we downgraded BT to EW and upgraded TEF DE to OW, and we believe OW-rated VOD and ORA are de-risked vs. peers.

11:59 am
BT Group (BT.A:LSE): Last: 235.20, down 7.05 (-2.91%), High: 241.45, Low: 235.10, Volume: 10.88m

We note that [UK fibre] rollouts to date have been few and far between, but new ownership of CityFibre should change this and we see key stakeholders (broadband service providers, mobile network operators and government/regulator) all keen to see the alternative FTTH build model succeed, creating infrastructure competition for BT. We reduced our estimates, price target and rating accordingly, and see a rising overhang for the shares despite valuation support
